results.title: Comedy greats: Ronnie Barker
results.brief_description: This compilation is a tribute to the comic genius of Ronnie Barker, unconventional hero of television programs such as ‘The Two Ronnies’, ‘Porridge’ and ‘Open all hours’. This tape includes sketches and clips from ‘The Two Ronnies’, a showcase for both Barker and his pint sized companion, Ronnie Corbett, including sketches targeting Government Ministers, Civil Servants and Church figures. In ‘Porridge’, Barker plays to perfection the seasoned lifer of Slade Prison who devoted his sentence to conniving and getting the better of Mr McKay and any other screw that crossed his path. Roy Clarke’s ‘Open all hours’ provided viewers with another legendary character, Arkwright, the stuttering, tight fisted, lecherous, corner shop owner, as well as the supporting characters of G-G-G Granville (David Jason), and Nurse Gladys Emmanuel.

results.title: Comedy greats: Peter Cooke & Dudley Moore
results.brief_description: This film is a collection of some of the infectious comic skits conceived and performed by Peter Cook and Dudley Moore that were to influence and inspire a generation of performers with their fresh and innovative style. Collected from their landmark 60’s TV show, “Not only but also”, this video samples some of the best, to include; Bo Dudley, The Leaping Nuns, Roger and Sir discussing ‘the opposite number and how Roger came to be’, the moving life story of acclaimed Finnish film star of the 30’s Bargo (aka Anna Nigma), Pete and Dud discussing how they’ve rejected a host of screen sirens from Betty Grable to Anna Magnani. Including many other skits, they particularly enjoy poking fun at the film industry and the art world in general. Their repartee and affection for each other is obvious, especially when together they employ a number of techniques to prevent themselves from laughing, including stuffing their mouths with food.

results.title: Comedian harmonists
results.creator_credit: Perathon, Iduna, Bavaria Film, Senator and Joseph Vilsmaier
results.brief_description: A dramatised account of the legendary German singing group ‘Comedian Harmonists’. Consisting of five singers and a pianist this close harmony group combined smooth melodies and comedy routines, performing jazz songs and German favorites in their own idiosyncratic style. They sang in several languages and starred in more than a dozen films. Vilsmaier tells the story of the groups rise to fame, their international success in the late twenties and early thirties, and their demise in 1934 when the Nazis branded their music as ‘degraded’ and prohibited it- three of the six musicians were Jewish. Essentially an affectionate tribute to the group, the film adopts the style of the traditional musical biopic. As with his earlier films ‘Herbstmilch’, ‘Rama Dama’ and ‘Stalingrad’, in this film Vilsmaier once again focuses on Germany in the 1930’s effectively portraying the treatment of Jewish artists during the National Socialism-Era. Cast includes Ben Becker, Heino Ferch, Ulrich Noethen, Heinrich Schafmeister, Kai Wiesinger, Katja Riemann, Meret Becker and Otto Sander. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Come September
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Robert Rothols
results.brief_description: This film was made during the Centenary Royal Show in 1972, to commemorate 100 years of traditional partnership between the Department of Agriculture and the Royal Agriculture Society in the Royal Show. Using locations sound and music only, the film aims to give an impression of the contrasting facets of the Melbourne Show, and how it sets out to attract a wide range of people, mainly from urban areas.
